nodes.claim: Apartheid divestment was chaos; why repeat it?
nodes.response: Apartheid divestment proved you can stand on ethics without breaking returns. Our firm’s policy embraces that precedent: we run apartheid-free portfolios with documented process and rely on sustained, multi-channel pressure—divestment plus engagement—just as history shows.

nodes.claim: BDS is illegal in our state.
nodes.response: State procurement laws target country boycotts. A conduct-based screen—grounded in UN Guiding Principles and applied to any violator—has survived review and mirrors how public systems like UC Regents structure exclusions.

nodes.claim: Divesting violates our ERISA fiduciary duty.
nodes.response: ERISA requires a prudent pecuniary case, not silence. DOL guidance confirms fiduciaries may weigh conduct risks when they affect returns, and our policy keeps financial guardrails such as tracking-error caps, override clauses, and independent consultant opinions that show we are mitigating risk, not trading returns for politics.

nodes.claim: We should keep the holdings and just engage.
nodes.response: Consultants note engagement has limits when risks are tied to illegal conduct or unresponsive governance. Cambridge Associates and Callan both advise pairing escalation with divestment when conduct gaps persist, and our staged policy documents that the risk is material and that we exhausted less disruptive tools first.

nodes.claim: This policy exposes us to discrimination claims.
nodes.response: Advisory Opinion 2025-04A shows the answer is to tighten the language, not abandon the policy. We rely on neutral conduct-based criteria validated by UN data and maintain counsel-reviewed override logs so the screen targets documented violations everywhere, not any protected class or geography.

nodes.claim: Divestment is ineffective; someone else just buys the shares.
nodes.response: The primary effects are reputational and in primary capital markets. Policies influence lenders, underwriters, and index providers and shift the cost of capital for targeted issuers.

nodes.claim: Divestment will significantly hurt performance and beneficiaries.
nodes.response: Naive exclusions can be costly, but professional managers use optimization and tracking-error limits to preserve factor exposures and benchmark-like returns.

nodes.claim: ESG has underperformed/We're moving away from values investing.
nodes.response: Our approach is high-active-share, research-driven investing—not an index fad. Ethical Capital's growth strategy has delivered benchmark-like returns while holding higher cash-flow yield companies, showing exclusion discipline can coexist with market performance.

nodes.claim: Exclusions reduce diversification too much.
nodes.response: Well-designed policies are narrow and conduct-based. Managers maintain diversification across sectors and factors while removing a limited set of issuers that breach defined standards.

nodes.claim: Exclusions violate fiduciary duty.
nodes.response: Fiduciary duty requires prudence, loyalty, and attention to material risk and client objectives. Values alignment and risk management can be implemented within a disciplined, return-seeking mandate.

nodes.claim: Divesting or adding MRIs violates our duty to maximize returns.
nodes.response: UPMIFA and IRS guidance both recognize that mission can be part of prudence. Boards that document risk, return, and mission factors in a prudence memo satisfy ordinary business care while reducing reputational and regulatory risk.

nodes.claim: If we fund MRIs or PRIs, we will erode the corpus and jeopardize grants.
nodes.response: PRIs count toward the 5% payout and recycle capital as repayments arrive; MRIs live in the endowment and can grow the base for future distributions. The IRS payout rules stay intact as long as the foundation keeps the 5% floor.

nodes.claim: How do we define 'settlement involvement'?
nodes.response: Use objective sources: UN databases, AFSC Investigate, and vendor ESG datasets itemize settlement-linked projects. Policies trigger off this evidence and require periodic review.

nodes.claim: How do you know these activist lists aren't biased?
nodes.response: We do not outsource ethics to third-party lists. About 40% of our exclusions are unique because we rebuild evidence in-house and document every call; activist data is an input, not the final answer.

nodes.claim: Selling blocks or risky assets will weaken surplus and hurt growth.
nodes.response: RBC math runs the other direction: shedding high-charge assets lifts statutory surplus and frees capital for higher-ROE lines. We are redeploying that surplus into regulated, admitted assets that keep growth on track.

nodes.claim: Rating agencies will punish us for shrinking the balance sheet.
nodes.response: Analysts reward capital adequacy and risk profile improvements. We are delivering pro-forma models that show higher redundancy at target ratings and engaging Moody's, S&P, Fitch, and AM Best before the announcement.

nodes.claim: Israeli companies provide essential technology/services.
nodes.response: A conduct-first policy distinguishes between legitimate business and grave rights violations. Exclusions target companies whose revenue or technology is tied to occupation abuses; suppliers meeting standards remain investable.

nodes.claim: MSCI or Sustainability ratings are more credible than activist data.
nodes.response: We build proprietary screens because mainstream ratings are inconsistent and often influenced by commercial incentives. Specialist intelligence (AFSC, UN) identifies issues faster, and we overlay that insight with widely-used index tools for transparent delivery.

nodes.claim: Our endowment/foundation documents prohibit political positions.
nodes.response: Conduct-based policies focus on fiduciary risk, not partisan statements. UC Regents' guidelines and UTS's SRI history show boards can codify exclusions as part of their duty to manage reputational and legal risk.

nodes.claim: Our index funds can't accommodate exclusions.
nodes.response: Major providers offer screened versions of core indexes, and mandates can overlay exclusion lists via optimization. Public pensions already run Israel/settlement screens inside benchmark-aware vehicles.

nodes.claim: Our investment consultant/manager won't implement this.
nodes.response: Ask for transparency about current constraints. Managers already deliver exclusion mandates; mainstream ESG providers offer screened benchmarks, and active oversight keeps implementation honest even when broad-market funds remain.

nodes.claim: Divesting for conduct reasons is illegal under anti-ESG laws.
nodes.response: Most statutes—including Texas SB13—allow actions tied to financially material risk or legal compliance. Document risk analysis, maintain boycott compliance logs, and show the decision protects beneficiaries, not politics.

nodes.claim: We do not have capacity to run a transparent divestment process.
nodes.response: Sunshine compliance is manageable with a structured calendar: notice postings, public packets, and documented prudence memos. Other funds have followed the same governance playbook without violating open-meeting rules.

nodes.claim: Settlement products are a tiny portion of these companies' revenues.
nodes.response: Even small revenue lines can signal structural risk: Caterpillar and Israeli banks face lawsuits, exclusions, and credit pressure tied to settlement activity. Screening reallocates capital to resilient issuers.

nodes.claim: The board doesn't have authority to make investment decisions.
nodes.response: Boards set policy; staff and consultants implement. UC Regents and other fiduciary boards codify exclusions in IPS language while delegating execution to investment teams under defined tracking-error limits.

nodes.claim: The situation is too complex for binary decisions.
nodes.response: Policies can blend process and precision. Evergreen State College defused protests by launching a task force, while Free Money highlights that continued dialogue about ethics and finance is itself part of responsible governance.

nodes.claim: This creates legal liability/litigation risk.
nodes.response: Documented policy, credible sourcing, and alignment with fiduciary duties provide cover. Large funds like NBIM and PFZW publish their rationale and have avoided litigation by sticking to evidence-based conduct standards.

nodes.claim: This distracts from our core mission.
nodes.response: Mission and finance are intertwined. The Free Money conversation notes divestment debates deepen understanding of finance's role, while campuses like SFSU tailored policies that supported student learning without derailing institutional objectives.

nodes.claim: This is virtue signaling that won't change anything.
nodes.response: Our clients' signals become shared policy. Every valid alert we receive is researched and added to firm-wide exclusions, and our flagship growth strategy has matched MSCI ACWI while staying values-aligned—so the work is both communal and financially credible.

nodes.claim: This politicizes our investment process.
nodes.response: Ignoring credible violations is itself a political stance. We use ethical screening as an active risk-management decision—protecting portfolios from legal, reputational, and stranded-asset exposure identified in our screening policy.

nodes.claim: This requires ongoing monitoring we can't maintain.
nodes.response: Set cadence and delegate: many policies mandate annual reviews plus event-driven updates fed by third-party alerts. Consultants and managers absorb the monitoring, reporting back through dashboards.

nodes.claim: This sets dangerous precedent for future exclusions.
nodes.response: Institutions already manage multiple ethical screens. UTS and SFSU frame new exclusions as extensions of long-standing SRI policies, proving conduct standards can evolve while staying disciplined.

nodes.claim: This sounds expensive or complicated—where do I even start?
nodes.response: Ethical screening is messy in practice—that’s why investors hire professionals to map the evidence, translate it into exclusions, and keep the process on track.

nodes.claim: This undermines academic freedom and exchange.
nodes.response: Universities exist for inquiry. Ashby Monk and Kelly Grotke highlight that divestment conversations deepen learning and institutional character; policies can target financial holdings while protecting academic collaboration.

nodes.claim: UN databases are politically motivated and unreliable.
nodes.response: Treat activist research as the specialist edge. Ground-level groups like AFSC or the UN database track evidence sooner than generalized ESG vendors; large funds (e.g., KLP) use them as the investigative spine and apply mainstream index tools for implementation.

nodes.claim: We don't have the expertise/resources to evaluate these companies.
nodes.response: Leverage third-party intelligence and manager tools: AFSC Investigate provides evidence packs, and screened indexes from MSCI/FTSE offer plug-and-play implementation with documented tracking-error budgets.

nodes.claim: We lack precedent from peer institutions.
nodes.response: Peer action is growing: institutions from SFSU to Union Theological Seminary and pension giants like KLP have adopted universal human-rights screens. They communicate the policy as a continuity of existing SRI principles.

nodes.claim: We need engagement, not divestment.
nodes.response: Escalation ladders work: institutions like the Church of England and Danish pensions engage first, set time-bound objectives, and divest when companies fail to remedy violations—preserving credibility and risk discipline.

nodes.claim: We're a global institution serving diverse stakeholders.
nodes.response: Global fiduciaries already run conduct screens. NBIM and KLP manage worldwide portfolios while excluding companies tied to occupation abuses, demonstrating universal standards work at scale.

nodes.claim: What about China/Saudi Arabia/other countries?
nodes.response: Apply one standard everywhere: our policy covers any issuer implicated in grave violations—Israeli, Chinese, American, or otherwise—using international law and third-party evidence as triggers.

sections.ask: Clarify mandate limits and adopt best-efforts exclusions with transparent rationale.
sections.implementation: Constraints consistent with reserve management; avoid market disruption.
sections.reporting: Public statement of limits and methods; periodic review.
sections.risk: Mandate-consistent risk posture with minimal deviation from reserve benchmarks.

sections.ask: Commission a Divestment Exposure Assessment that documents how conduct risk links to financial exposure and captures ERISA prudence.
sections.implementation: Use external data to build risk dossiers, run tracking error and liability aware modeling, and deliver scenario analysis without breaking the de risking glidepath.
sections.reporting: Provide a prudence memo, funded status sensitivity tables, and a calendar for policy updates shared with the sponsor treasury team.
sections.risk: Maintain diversification, document thresholds and override clauses, and align with DOL guidance so the assessment shows control rather than activism.

sections.ask: Mission-aligned exclusion framework with committee governance and stakeholder transparency.
sections.implementation: Manager constraints or screened indexes; publish rationales; staged implementation.
sections.reporting: Public rationale per issuer; annual reviews with community communication.
sections.risk: Maintain diversification and factor integrity; narrow scope to grave conduct.

sections.ask: Program-aligned exclusions that reduce reputational risk while preserving portfolio discipline.
sections.implementation: Simplified screened index or manager constraints; phased timeline.
sections.reporting: Public list and brief rationales; annual update.
sections.risk: Emphasize conduct screens to mitigate drawdowns from controversies.

sections.ask: Define issuer screens/approved issuer lists consistent with procurement and governance rules.
sections.implementation: Apply issuer criteria to government bond portfolios; best-efforts approach with legal review; transparent exceptions process.
sections.reporting: Publish issuer criteria, approved lists, and update cadence.
sections.risk: Avoid undue concentration; maintain liquidity and policy compliance.

sections.ask: Align personal or household savings with stated values and explain the exclusions in plain language.
sections.implementation: Use low-cost screened ETFs or managed accounts; document which companies are excluded and why.
sections.reporting: Keep a simple holdings list and revisit annually or after major portfolio changes.
sections.risk: Maintain emergency funds, diversification, and low fees while applying exclusions.

sections.ask: Adopt narrow conduct screens consistent with ALM and capital/rating requirements.
sections.implementation: Best-efforts exclusions; vendor screen overlays; maintain liquidity ladder.
sections.risk: Tight tracking-error; preserve liability matching and capital buffers.

sections.ask: Consultant memo and manager mandates for conduct-based exclusions; define guardrails.
sections.implementation: Passive screened index or benchmark-aware constraints; phased divestment to minimize costs; maintain diversification.
sections.reporting: Quarterly one-page dashboard; publish criteria and exclusion list.
sections.risk: Tracking-error limit (e.g., ≤30 bps) and factor neutrality by vendor.

sections.ask: Adopt conduct-based exclusions with a formal ethics/oversight process and public rationales.
sections.implementation: Multi-manager mandates with optimization constraints; preserve factor/sector neutrality; staged rebalances.
sections.reporting: Publish exclusion list and rationale; periodic reviews and appeals mechanism; transparent methodology.
sections.risk: Explicit tracking-error budget (e.g., 15–30 bps) and central risk model governance.

nodes.title: Link divestment to credit and liquidity management
nodes.body: Credit downgrades and liquidity stress—like the recent Israel bond freeze—provide fiduciary cover for rebalancing into aligned issuers.

nodes.title: Report exclusions like any other governance control
nodes.body: Publish criteria, changes, and rationale on a set cadence so oversight bodies and auditors can verify compliance without politicizing the process.

nodes.title: Use approved issuer lists to stay compliant
nodes.body: Define a transparent approved issuer list that aligns with procurement statutes and discloses best-efforts limits for bond purchases.

nodes.title: Civil-rights scrutiny requires neutral conduct-based criteria
nodes.body: Advisory Opinion 2025-04A shows the DOL will flag investment programs that could violate federal civil-rights law even when ERISA process is sound. Divestment language must stay geography-neutral, cite objective UN conduct lists, and undergo civil-rights review so opponents cannot reframe the policy as discrimination.

nodes.title: DB litigation shields do not protect DC lineups
nodes.body: The 2024 dismissal of Wong v. NYCERS rested on DB participants lacking standing because promised benefits are formula-driven. Corporate DC plans lack that protection, so divestment moves need heightened documentation of pecuniary analysis, participant communications, and consultant sign-off to withstand direct performance challenges.

nodes.title: Corporate divestment must rest on a pecuniary fiduciary case
nodes.body: ERISA binds corporate plan fiduciaries to act solely for participants and document prudent pecuniary analysis. Divestment policies need written prudence memos, legal counsel review, and consultant opinions that link conduct-based exclusions to sanctions, litigation, and reputational risk so the screen clearly mitigates financial exposure.

nodes.title: Implementation friction should shape the divestment brief
nodes.body: Consultants warn that pooled funds and illiquid partnerships cannot take bespoke screens overnight. Stage quick wins in liquid accounts, plan full manager searches for pooled mandates, and document trade-offs so the policy scope and timeline match what governance and vendors can actually deliver.

nodes.title: Regulatory whiplash demands hard guardrails
nodes.body: DOL guidance has swung from the 2020 financial-factors rule to the 2022 prudence rule and the pending 2025 reversal. The only durable strategy is to embed measurable controls such as tracking-error caps, diversification tests, override logs, and override clauses so the portfolio stays defensible regardless of which interpretation prevails.

nodes.title: Fiduciary duty and values alignment
nodes.body: Modern fiduciary guidance recognizes that material ESG risks and client objectives can be incorporated without abandoning prudent, return-seeking management.

nodes.title: Modern prudence standard supports mission-aligned portfolios
nodes.body: IRC §4944 still forbids jeopardizing investments, but Treasury regulations judge prudence at the time of decision and across the whole portfolio. Paired with IRS Notice 2015-62, boards can document mission-driven allocations as ordinary business care when they evaluate risk, return, and charitable purpose in one deliberative process.

nodes.title: 5% payout is the floor—use divestment to strengthen the base
nodes.body: The mandatory 5% distribution is calculated on the average fair market value of the foundation's assets. Mission-aligned MRIs can grow corpus value, increasing the dollar amount of future grants, while PRIs recycle returns into new qualifying distributions. Documenting this feedback loop answers worries about eroding purchasing power.

nodes.title: PRIs and MRIs give trustees two levers for mission capital
nodes.body: Program-related investments (PRIs) count toward the 5% payout and can recycle charitable capital, while mission-related investments (MRIs) sit in the endowment and pursue market-rate returns. Linking both in the investment policy statement clarifies when the foundation is deploying charitable risk capital versus permanent portfolio assets.

nodes.title: UPMIFA explicitly embeds mission into prudence analysis
nodes.body: UPMIFA directs fiduciaries to consider the charitable purposes of the institution when setting investment strategy, alongside risk, return, liquidity, and diversification. Referencing the statute in board minutes shows that aligning the endowment with mission is part of prudent oversight—not a deviation from it.

nodes.title: Link divestment to credit and liquidity management
nodes.body: Credit downgrades and liquidity stress—like the recent Israel bond freeze—provide fiduciary cover for rebalancing into aligned issuers.

nodes.title: Report exclusions like any other governance control
nodes.body: Publish criteria, changes, and rationale on a set cadence so oversight bodies and auditors can verify compliance without politicizing the process.

nodes.title: Use approved issuer lists to stay compliant
nodes.body: Define a transparent approved issuer list that aligns with procurement statutes and discloses best-efforts limits for bond purchases.

nodes.title: Specialized intelligence catches what ESG ratings miss
nodes.body: On-the-ground researchers (AFSC, UN) surface settlement and occupation ties long before generalized ESG vendors adjust their scores. Pair activist data for precision with mainstream index tools for implementation.

nodes.title: Start with your own accounts
nodes.body: List holdings in retirement and brokerage accounts, then shift into screened ETFs or managed accounts that match your risk profile while keeping emergency reserves intact.

nodes.title: Use the screened options your custodian already offers
nodes.body: Most platforms list values-screened ETFs and separate-account providers. Switching allocations usually takes minutes once you have the tickers and minimums.

nodes.title: Divestment unlocks ALM and capital efficiency
nodes.body: ALM teams can convert negative convexity positions and long asset-duration gaps into capital-efficient portfolios by selling high charge assets and redeploying into duration-matched replacements. The move raises return on required capital while shrinking C-3 interest rate charges.

nodes.title: Climate supervision accelerates conduct-based divestment
nodes.body: Supervisors are embedding climate and ESG risk into solvency reviews. ORSA, NAIC climate surveys, and emerging EU-style due diligence regimes incentivize insurers to exit high-carbon exposures and document the shift as prudent risk management rather than values-driven activism.

nodes.title: Implementation ladder ranges from overlays to impact sleeves
nodes.body: Insurers can stage divestment through a ladder: credit overlays to synthetically exit exposures, bespoke mandates or sidecars to outsource risk, full block sales to transfer liabilities, and mission-aligned private market sleeves that redeploy capital into justice-focused projects.

nodes.title: Rating agency dialogue should lead the transaction
nodes.body: Moody's, S&P, Fitch, and AM Best all translate divestment into capital adequacy, risk profile, and liquidity metrics. Deliver pro-forma models that show reduced high-risk assets, higher capital redundancy, and improved liquidity coverage so analysts can upgrade—or at least protect—the financial strength rating.

nodes.title: Regulatory guardrails turn divestment into a solvency tool
nodes.body: SAP restricts insurers to admitted assets, RBC assigns capital charges to every risk bucket, and ORSA demands a narrative showing resilience under stress. Proactive divestment from capital-inefficient holdings boosts statutory surplus, improves RBC ratios, and gives boards a defensible ORSA story before regulators ask for it.

nodes.title: Outcome: investments align with identity
nodes.body: Clear divestment criteria anchor portfolios in the institution’s stated ethics, letting trustees and staff demonstrate that capital flows reflect mission and fiduciary commitments. Alignment messaging reassures beneficiaries, donors, and community partners that investment actions match identity.

nodes.title: Outcome: mission trust reinforced
nodes.body: When boards drive divestment, they can show donors, students, and program staff that capital decisions back institutional values without jeopardising spending policies. Transparent trade plans and impact dashboards keep leadership, faculty, and community stakeholders aligned.

nodes.title: Outcome: documented compliance confidence
nodes.body: Conduct-based exclusions, optimization reports, and counsel sign-offs create an audit trail that satisfies fiduciary and statutory obligations. Regulators and attorneys general see proactive risk management, lowering litigation exposure and procurement challenges.

nodes.title: Outcome: stakeholder momentum sustained
nodes.body: Coalitions see tangible follow-through when portfolios exit targeted issuers and capital is redeployed toward community priorities. Publishing progress dashboards and reinvestment pipelines keeps organizers engaged and channels pressure into ongoing governance improvements.

nodes.title: Professional exclusions maintain benchmark-like performance
nodes.body: Large public funds implement conduct-based exclusions and continue to deliver returns close to their benchmarks by rebalancing and preserving factor exposures.

nodes.title: Anti-ESG statutes narrow pecuniary factors—but allow risk framing
nodes.body: Laws such as Texas SB13 and similar provisions restrict investment decisions that appear political. Fiduciaries can still act when they demonstrate material risk—sanctions, litigation, stranded assets—and maintain a compliance log tracking boycott lists and exemptions.

nodes.title: Exclusive-purpose clauses anchor divestment decisions
nodes.body: State constitutions and statutes—from California's Article XVI to Ohio's §145.11—make the duty to participants paramount. Conduct-based divestment must be framed as protecting beneficiaries from legal, financial, or operational risk, not as a political gesture.

nodes.title: Consultants can document explicit guardrails
nodes.body: Ask your consultant to publish tracking-error budgets, factor controls, and rebalancing cadence so trustees see how exclusions stay benchmark-aware.

nodes.title: Peer funds already run conduct screens
nodes.body: KLP, AkademikerPension, and PFZW have implemented occupation-related exclusions with neutral-to-positive performance impact—use their public reporting as precedent.

nodes.title: Specialized intelligence catches what ESG ratings miss
nodes.body: AFSC and UN research identify occupation-linked issuers early; combine their insight with customization from mainstream vendors to deliver results consultants can monitor.

nodes.title: Procedural prudence is the best defense
nodes.body: Courts look at process—documented analysis, expert input, and clear rationale—not just outcomes. Maintaining detailed minutes, prudence memos, and consultant opinions turns a divestment decision into evidence of prudence if it is ever challenged.

nodes.title: Sunshine laws require public choreography
nodes.body: Open-meeting statutes like the Brown Act dictate timelines for notice, agendas, and public comment. Successful divestment campaigns plan resolutions, RFPs, and consultant presentations so they meet statutory posting windows and withstand scrutiny.

nodes.title: Specialized intelligence catches what ESG ratings miss
nodes.body: On-the-ground researchers (AFSC, UN) surface settlement and occupation ties long before generalized ESG vendors adjust their scores. Pair activist data for precision with MSCI/FTSE tools for delivery, so implementation stays repeatable.

nodes.title: Escalation triggers move institutions up the ladder
nodes.body: Failed engagements, accelerator protest wins, and new compliance signals (like DOL civil-rights advisories) are the events boards can document to justify stepping from stewardship into screening or divestment.

nodes.title: Portfolio plumbing must match the chosen tier
nodes.body: Whichever rung you pick, refresh manager RFPs, build screened benchmarks, and extend risk reports so tracking error, impact metrics, and override logs show up alongside returns.

nodes.title: Tier 1: Monitoring builds the human-rights risk map
nodes.body: Start by piping specialist human-rights datasets into the portfolio risk stack to flag controversies and liability exposure without touching allocations. Treat AFSC investigative data and MSCI controversy scores like any other risk factor so trustees can see where holdings diverge from policy goals.

nodes.title: Tier 2: Stewardship demands an escalation ladder
nodes.body: Document a stewardship policy that names priority human-rights asks, assigns owners for company dialogue, and spells out when escalation flips from private meetings to proxy votes, public statements, and director-withhold campaigns.

nodes.title: Tier 3: Targeted screens make the first portfolio cut
nodes.body: Narrow exclusion lists anchored in UN or AFSC criteria let boards codify red lines, publish restricted issuers, and run performance against a custom screened benchmark so the policy impact stays auditable.

nodes.title: Tier 4: Positive and thematic tilts show what you fund
nodes.body: Allocating sleeves to human-rights solution themes and best-in-class issuers reframes the story from avoidance to proactive impact, backed by factor-aware ESG construction.

nodes.title: Tier 5: Full divestment delivers the hard break
nodes.body: When boards adopt conduct-based divestment statutes, publish the prohibited list, and stage the sell-down, they provide unmistakable proof that capital no longer backs the targeted harm and that policy guardrails can survive public scrutiny.

nodes.title: Tier 6: Impact carve-outs channel capital to affected communities
nodes.body: Dedicated private-market sleeves can finance Palestinian-led enterprises or justice-aligned infrastructure, pairing IRIS+ metrics with return targets so trustees see both impact and cash flow.

nodes.title: Tier 7: Mission-native partnerships align the whole enterprise
nodes.body: Building long-term partnerships with funds and founders whose sole mandate is justice turns the portfolio into a mission delivery system; it demands patient capital, board conviction, and narrative-rich reporting.

nodes.title: External stakeholders: convert campaign pressure into structured capital moves
nodes.body:
Strategy spectrum: responsive divest-reinvest mandates, coalition-built exclusion lists, community reinvestment pools, and transparency dashboards that track follow-through.
Implementation notes: co-design criteria with organizers, publish escalation ladders, and coordinate communications with governance, donor, and beneficiary groups.
Outcomes to monitor: stakeholder sentiment shifts, media/regulator responses, capital redeployment volumes, and engagement opportunities created by divestment decisions.

nodes.title: Internal leadership: align mission and capital without losing discipline
nodes.body:
Strategy spectrum: mission-screen overlays, carve-out impact sleeves, delegated investment committee mandates, and donor-aligned policy statements with phased implementation schedules.
Implementation notes: connect divestment criteria to charter language, donor restrictions, and campus/program goals; pilot with separate accounts or manager guidelines before system-wide rollout.
Outcomes to monitor: mission KPI dashboards, spending policy resilience, peer benchmarking, and qualitative feedback loops from leadership and program staff.

nodes.title: Regulatory drivers: codify compliance-first divestment
nodes.body:
Strategy spectrum: conduct-based exclusion lists, optimized overlays on core benchmarks, or segregated compliance sleeves to satisfy fiduciary and statutory directives.
Implementation notes: lean on attorney general guidance, procurement statutes, and consultant attestations; pair exclusions with tracking-error budgets and factor neutrality tests.
Outcomes to monitor: variance vs policy benchmark (<50 bps TE targets), documented liability risk reduction, regulator-ready audit trails, and stakeholder briefings that underline prudence.

nodes.title: Tracking error and factor neutrality
nodes.body: Exclusions can be implemented with explicit tracking-error budgets and factor controls so the portfolio stays close to its benchmark while meeting policy goals.

nodes.title: CIO Implementation Note
nodes.markdown: Implementation focuses on preserving benchmark alignment: specify a tracking-error budget, maintain factor neutrality, use vendor screened indexes or optimization constraints, and phase trades to avoid divestment shocks.

nodes.text: Official institutions can clarify mandate limits, apply best-efforts exclusions, and provide transparent rationales and constraints.
Corporate plans can update the IPS, adopt a screened index or constraints with minimal overhead, and maintain de-risking alignment.
Endowments can align with mission through a committee process, publish rationales, and maintain prudent risk controls.
An endowment can reflect mission and educational values with transparent criteria and periodic reviews.
Foundations can align programs and portfolios, reduce reputational risk through clear criteria, and use simplified implementation paths.

We can align investments with basic human rights using professional, benchmark-aware implementation. Large institutions already use narrowly scoped exclusions while maintaining diversification and risk controls.
Government investors (city/county/state) can apply issuer screens/approved lists for bonds, observe procurement/governance limits, and report with best-efforts language.
For government bond portfolios, define approved issuer lists and issuer screens consistent with procurement rules and transparency.
Public-fund advisors can translate advocacy into policy language: cite municipal precedents, supply approved issuer models, and brief council members on sunshine-law friendly reporting cadences.
Treasury staff can lead with compliance: align exclusions with procurement statutes, present approved issuer watchlists, and document that liquidity and cash-flow schedules stay intact.
Individual investors can align personal or household savings with their values using low-cost screened funds while keeping diversification and emergency reserves intact.
For friends or family, emphasize aligning personal savings with shared values and keep the steps concrete and jargon-free.
Insurance portfolios can adopt narrow conduct screens consistent with ALM and capital/rating constraints, emphasizing best-efforts and risk integrity.
Consultants can bring carriers a capital-friendly roadmap: propose conduct screens that respect ALM tests, provide optimization outputs, and script regulator-ready documentation.

Insurance investment teams should tie exclusions to liability management: highlight RBC-friendly screened options, coordinate with actuaries on duration, and show rating agency expectations stay satisfied.
Advisors can frame alignment as reputational risk management: benchmark peer endowments, package screened fund menus, and show spending policy resilience under the exclusion set.
Mission-driven investment staff can translate campus and program demands into policy: map donor restrictions, propose phased exclusions, and pair mission statements with investment risk notes.
Consultants can bring trustees a vote-ready memo: define conduct triggers, outline optimized benchmark overlays, and hand over templates that document prudence while staff executes.

Staff can frame this as fiduciary risk governance: pull exposure runs from managers, cite peer pensions already using conduct screens, and show how tracking-error guardrails keep liabilities protected.
Public plans can use consultant/manager mandates, set a tracking-error guardrail, and phase implementation while keeping beneficiaries’ risk/return in focus.
Public pensions can adopt a clear exclusion policy with consultant support, preserve diversification, and report progress without sacrificing fiduciary discipline.
External partners can add independent credibility: document human-rights triggers, align with IMF governance guidance, and demonstrate tracking-error caps for reserve portfolios.
Sovereign reserve teams can ground the ask in mandate protection: reference Santiago Principles, show best-efforts exclusions preserve liquidity, and schedule periodic policy reviews.
A sovereign fund can implement conduct-based exclusions via a formal ethics process, public rationales, and factor-neutral optimization with explicit tracking-error budgets.

nodes.title: Policy alignment criteria
bullets: Documented, explainable criteria with public rationales (no black boxes)
Conduct-first screening for risk mitigation; product screens for categorical harms when aligned with mission
Evidence-based decisions using primary and reputable sources with citations
Regular review cadence (at least annually) and event-driven updates
Escalation path from engagement to exclusion; documented exceptions with time limits
Implementation discipline: tracking-error guardrails, diversification, factor neutrality, phased trading
Transparency: publish criteria and lists subject to prudent trading and confidentiality

nodes.title: Screening intelligence

variants.body:
- **Identify business model fragility.** Systematic exclusions focus attention on issuers whose operating models exhibit hidden tail risks (legal, reputational, sovereign), fragile customer bases, or supply chains exposed to human-rights litigation. (Sources: AFSC Investigate)
- **Knowledge compounds.** Each exclusion deepens understanding of your opportunity set—linking policy pledges (apartheid-free, harm avoidance) to concrete portfolio changes and documenting the institutional lesson. (Sources: Ethical Capital: Investment Screening Policy)
- **Integration cadence as practice standard.** Treat credible database updates as investment intelligence: aim to assess and integrate material changes within 30 days (faster when practicable) with documented rationale. (Sources: AFSC Investigate)

nodes.title: Government Policy Template
nodes.markdown:
Approved Issuers Policy (template)

Purpose: Maintain an Approved Issuers List for fixed-income investing that aligns treasury practices with ethical standards and risk controls while complying with law and procurement rules.

Criteria: Exclude issuers with credible, public evidence of severe human rights violations (including complicity in violations under international humanitarian law). Consider authoritative sources (sanctions lists, court decisions, official investigations) and reputable human-rights reporting.

Portfolio Constraints: Preserve target duration, credit quality, liquidity, and diversification consistent with the investment policy and statutes.

Process: Treasurer (or designee) maintains Approved and Prohibited Issuer lists; legal/procurement review; annual review and event-driven updates; exceptions require written rationale, legal review, time limits, and notification to the governing body.

Transparency & Reporting: Publish criteria and current lists subject to prudent trading and confidentiality; report changes and rationales at least annually.

Compliance: This policy operates subject to state law, investment statutes, and procurement rules; in case of conflict, legal requirements prevail.

nodes.title: Model Resolution
nodes.markdown:
RESOLVED: That the {localName} shall adopt a conduct-based investment exclusion policy, instructing its investment managers to avoid purchasing or holding securities of companies for which there is credible, public evidence of severe human rights violations, including complicity in violations under international humanitarian law; and be it further

RESOLVED: That the {localName} directs its investment managers to implement this policy using professional portfolio construction techniques that maintain diversification and risk controls, including explicit tracking error limits relative to the benchmark; and be it further

RESOLVED: That the {localName} will publish an exclusion rationale and a public list of excluded issuers, reviewed at least annually; and be it further

RESOLVED: That the {localName} will phase implementation over an orderly period and report progress and holdings, subject to prudent trading and confidentiality constraints.

nodes.title: Divestment Exposure Assessment documents ERISA prudence
nodes.body: Corporate fiduciaries can evidence loyalty and prudence by running a Divestment Exposure Assessment that ties conduct risk to financial impact, applies the DOL ESG rule, and produces a documented prudence file. Skipping that analysis leaves the board exposed to claims that it ignored material risk.

nodes.title: Module 1: qualitative risk dossier
nodes.body: Module 1 builds a documented risk dossier: screen holdings for conduct controversies across ESG categories, log sanctions and litigation exposure, and map stakeholder pressure so ERISA counsel can link qualitative signals to financial risk.

nodes.title: Module 2: quantify exposure and funded-status impact
nodes.body: Module 2 quantifies exposure by comparing portfolio weights to the benchmark, modeling tracking error and factor drift, and running VaR, ES, and funded status sensitivity for each exclusion scenario so trustees see the capital impact.

nodes.title: Module 3: scenario deck for tail risk
nodes.body: Module 3 delivers a scenario deck that stress tests sanctions shocks, catastrophic litigation, and systemic supply chain disruption so the board can see how severe events would hit returns, liquidity, and contribution requirements.

nodes.title: Module 4: mitigation roadmap and triggers
nodes.body: Module 4 turns findings into an action roadmap with trigger thresholds, override clauses, and an IPS update schedule so staff know when to escalate issues and the sponsor sees a ready governance plan.

nodes.title: Integrated Policy Framework
nodes.description: Board-ready reference for governance, risk, and stewardship controls drawn from global standards.

nodes.title: Policy clause: duty of care
nodes.markdown: "The Manager must use reasonable care and prudent judgment when managing the assets of the institution. This duty of prudence requires the systematic and explicit inclusion of financially material Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) factors into all investment analysis and investment decision-making processes, consistent with the investment time horizons of the beneficiaries."

nodes.title: Policy clause: duty of loyalty
nodes.markdown: "The Manager must place the interests of the institution's beneficiaries before their own interests at all times. This duty of loyalty requires the Manager to evaluate both product-based and conduct-based risks within the portfolio and to act on undiversifiable systemic threats—such as climate change and biodiversity loss—that can impair long-term economic performance and, consequently, beneficiary outcomes."

nodes.title: Policy clause: beneficiary consultation
nodes.markdown: "The Manager will establish and maintain a formal process to surface and document the sustainability-related preferences of the institution's beneficiaries. Those preferences will inform investment analysis, stewardship priorities, and reporting—regardless of whether the preferences are deemed financially material in the short term—and the Manager will provide periodic updates describing how they were incorporated."

nodes.title: ESG risk blends conduct failures and systemic shocks
nodes.body: Product exclusions flag direct links to contested revenue, while conduct screens surface legal, regulatory, and reputational breaches. Systemic risks—climate transition, biodiversity collapse, social unrest—propagate through markets even when a portfolio is diversified. Policy must capture both layers so trustees can evidence duty of care and loyalty in a single narrative.

nodes.title: Modern fiduciary duty treats material ESG as mandatory
nodes.body: CFA Institute's Asset Manager Code requires managers to exercise prudent judgment with a reasonable and adequate basis; PRI's Fiduciary Duty in the 21st Century shows that ignoring financially material ESG drivers breaches that standard. Anchoring screens in documented risk factors keeps divestment well inside the duty of care.

nodes.title: ISSB disclosure makes board oversight auditable
nodes.body: OECD governance principles define the board's accountability, and IFRS S2 now requires institutions to publish how directors oversee climate and sustainability risk. Sloppy processes become public evidence, so boards need documented competencies, education plans, and committee charters that withstand disclosure.

nodes.title: COSO ERM turns conduct risk into a board-controlled system
nodes.body: COSO's five-component ERM framework links tone at the top, risk appetite, monitoring, and reporting. Using it as the house standard makes conduct screening, internal audits, and escalation policies auditable instead of ad hoc.

nodes.title: ICMA principles are the floor for sustainable debt diligence
nodes.body: The ICMA Green, Social, and Sustainability-Linked Bond Principles spell out use-of-proceeds rules, evaluation processes, tracking, and reporting. Mandating alignment plus third-party reviews keeps labelled debt from slipping into greenwashing.

nodes.title: OECD due diligence gives investors a universal risk process
nodes.body: OECD's responsible business conduct guidance lays out a six-step loop for spotting, mitigating, and remediating harms across portfolios and supply chains. Treating it as a standing expectation closes the gap between public equities, credit, and private-market mandates.

nodes.title: ISO 37002 whistleblowing keeps retaliation from burying risk
nodes.body: ISO 37002 requires trusted intake channels, impartial investigations, and explicit retaliation safeguards. Tying those requirements to stewardship asks lets activists probe whether issuers can surface misconduct tied to harmful conduct.

nodes.title: Master reporting matrices stop policy drift
nodes.body: Pairing IFRS S2 reporting needs with COSO information flows creates a single matrix that schedules heatmaps, scenario tests, variance logs, and override reviews. Committees get an auditable trail proving the IPS is enforced.

nodes.title: Independent assurance is the new baseline for sustainability data
nodes.body: IFRS S2 pushes comparable climate reporting, and firms like Proskauer warn boards to treat assurance like the financial audit cycle. Annual external attestation on climate metrics and controls keeps disclosures credible with beneficiaries and regulators.

nodes.title: Documented escalation triggers turn stewardship into leverage
nodes.body: PRI guidance, Glass Lewis, and leading managers like UBP all require engagement milestones and consequences. When timelines, voting actions, and divestment triggers are written into policy, staff can escalate without waiting for ad hoc approvals.

nodes.text: Stand up an IPS variance log and override register with board sign-off and quarterly review.
Build a master reporting matrix that calendars heatmaps, scenario tests, variance reviews, and ISSB-aligned disclosures.
Audit whistleblowing controls against ISO 37002 and publish remediation timelines for any gaps.
Run a COSO ERM maturity assessment that maps conduct-risk ownership, reporting cadence, and escalation routes.

nodes.title: Policy-first divestment scaffold
nodes.markdown:
- **Define formal guardrails.** Amend the IPS with conduct criteria, risk-appetite statements, variance logs, and an override clause so leadership cannot ignore breaches.
- **Wire the reporting loop.** Stand up a COSO-aligned reporting matrix that feeds boards heatmaps, scenario tests, and engagement status alongside draft ISSB disclosures.
- **Codify escalation.** Document engagement milestones, voting actions, and divestment triggers tied to whistleblower protections so staff can escalate without improvising.
